title: 112_hr6530
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2012". The Global Free Internet Act of 2012 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products. It supports policies that encourage technology standards, respect user privacy, promote innovation, and allow for the free flow of information and trade in Internet-related goods and services. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies contrary to a free, open Internet, including mandating unique technology standards, sponsoring unauthorized access to networks, and restricting Internet communications in a discriminatory manner. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that threaten the interests of the United States by disrupting the free flow of information on the Internet and compromising its functionality. This includes blocking, filtering, monitoring, and imposing market access requirements that discriminate against Internet-related goods, services, and content from other countries. The adoption of policies by certain governments and international bodies threatens the United States by disrupting the free flow of information on the Internet. This includes promoting "national Internets," harming US workers and businesses, and putting the utility of the Internet at risk for open communication and commerce. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established to address threats to the free flow of information on the Internet posed by certain government policies. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of four individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties, nominated by the public and appointed by the President. The Task Force also includes the leader of the majority party in the Senate. Members serve renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of individuals with expertise in Internet policy and civil liberties appointed by various government officials for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. Members include representatives from the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, leaders from the Senate and House of Representatives, as well as key government officials. The Task Force on the Global Internet, under the Department of Commerce, includes experts in Internet policy appointed by government officials. It collaborates with various federal agencies to develop strategies addressing international trade restrictions on Internet-related goods. The Task Force on the Global Internet, led by the Department of Commerce, aims to develop strategies to counteract government policies that hinder international trade in Internet-related goods and services, impede the free flow of information, or threaten the open nature of the Internet. They consult with civil society groups, coordinate federal agency activities, and prepare reports and action plans. The Task Force on the Global Internet, led by the Department of Commerce, aims to counteract government policies hindering international trade in Internet-related goods and services, impeding the free flow of information, or threatening the open nature of the Internet. They coordinate federal agency activities, prepare reports and action plans, hold public hearings, solicit public comments, and appoint a civilian Task Force member to lead and serve as a point of contact. The Task Force on the Global Internet, led by the Department of Commerce, aims to counteract government policies hindering international trade in Internet-related goods and services, impeding the free flow of information, or threatening the open nature of the Internet. They coordinate federal agency activities, prepare reports and action plans, hold public hearings, solicit public comments, and appoint a civilian Task Force member to lead and serve as a point of contact. SEC. 4. REPORT AND ACTION PLAN TO THE PRESIDENT AND CONGRESS. The Task Force will annually report to the President and Congress on acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access or impose unjustifiable restrictions on Internet-related trade and technology standards. The Task Force will report annually to the President and Congress on measures that could hinder fair market access, impose unjustifiable restrictions on Internet-related trade, or threaten US interests in global Internet communications. The report will estimate the impact on US commerce, Internet users, and the functioning of the Internet, designate priority concerns, outline a response strategy for Federal departments and agencies, and provide information on actions taken in response to previous reports. The Task Force will provide annual reports on measures affecting fair market access and Internet trade, including actions taken in response to previous reports. Reports may include a classified annex, and public participation is encouraged through notices, hearings, and a Task Force website. Coordination with relevant executive entities is required. The Task Force publishes information on its activities, consults with executive branches and civil society groups, and considers information from various sources. The report and action plan are published in the Federal Register, omitting certain information. SEC. 5. The United States Trade Representative must initiate an investigation within 30 days of each annual report and action plan transmission, under sections 301 through 304 of the Trade Act of 1974, regarding foreign government practices identified as priority concerns. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice will review and investigate. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General will review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. The term "antitrust laws" includes the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. The Task Force will submit a report assessing existing trade agreements related to Internet trade, technology standards, Internet security, information flow, and user protection. It will also recommend modifications or new agreements to advance these objectives. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals. The Task Force will submit a report on existing trade agreements related to Internet trade, technology standards, security, information flow, and user protection. Congress believes future trade agreements should include these goals and public participation is encouraged in the process. The Task Force publishes information on its activities, consults with relevant federal departments, shares information with civil society groups, and considers input from various sources. The Task Force will publish its report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding certain information transmitted to Congress. The Task Force coordinates training with various entities for government officials and standard-setting bodies. It also establishes a process for receiving input from businesses and organizations.
